lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn What late misfortune is befalln King Edward

lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: What! loss of some pitchd battle against Warwick

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner, Either betrayd by falsehood of his guard Or by his foe surprised at unawares: And, as I further have to understand, Is new committed to the Bishop of York, Fell Warwicks brother and by that our foe.

lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: These news I must confess are full of grief Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may: Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Till then fair hope must hinder lifes decay. And I the rather wean me from despair For love of Edwards offspring in my womb: This is it that makes me bridle passion And bear with mildness my misfortunes cross Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear And stop the rising of bloodsucking sighs, Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown King Edwards fruit, true heir to the English crown.

lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: But, madam, where is Warwick then become

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: I am informd that he comes towards London, To set the crown once more on Henrys head: Guess thou the rest King Edwards friends must down, But, to prevent the tyrants violence, For trust not him that hath once broken faith, Ill hence forthwith unto the sanctuary, To save at least the heir of Edwards right: There shall I rest secure from force and fraud. Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly: If Warwick take us we are sure to die.
